columns.text: In this problem, we will compare two scenarios based on the concept of present value annuity.

For the rate, since it is compounded monthly, then there will be $12$ compounding periods in a year. This will give us a rate of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{0.07}{12}\\[15 pt]
&=0.00583
\end{aligned}$$

The monthly rate is $0.00583$

Now that we have the monthly rate, we can now solve for the present value annuity of the first scenario.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\$85,000\times\dfrac{1-\frac{1}{(1+0.00583)^{24}}}{0.00583}\\[15 pt]
&=\$85,000 \times 22.34\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,898,900
\end{aligned}$$

The present value for this is $\$1,898,900$

For the second scenario:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\$74,000\times\dfrac{1-\frac{1}{(1+0.00583)^{24}}}{0.00583}\\[15 pt]
&=\$74,000 \times 22.34\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,653,160
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of this is $\$1,653,160$

In the second option, however, there is an outright $\$20,000$ signing bonus. We will then add this to the value in Step 5 to get the total of the present value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\$1,653,160+\$20,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,673,160
\end{aligned}$$

The present value for the second scenario is $\$1,673,150$
Based on the values, it is better to get a cash flow of $\$85,000$ for two years since it has a higher present value compared to the other option.
